#id=1
#text=I live near the city of Santa Cruz and often take the 17X bus to the nearby city of San Jose .
#id=2
#text=It 's possible to get discount fares by paying for multiple rides in advance , but I usually pay cash , five dollars for one-way .
#id=3

#text=I get to my small town 's transit center early on weekday mornings , because the bus fills up quickly , and most good seats are already taken by riders who started their trip in downtown Santa Cruz .
#id=4
#text=We wait in line in civilized fashion .
#id=5
#text=Some people need only show the driver their pass , some shove a five-dollar bill into the fare machine efficiently .
#id=6
#text=But some fumble with small coins or ask other riders for change , which makes everyone in line restive .
#id=7
#text=Once on , riders can choose seats grouped around small tables , seats facing forward , or seats facing sideways .
#id=8
#text=Table seats are premium , since the bus has WiFi and many people bring laptops .
#id=9
#text=Others prefer seats in the back where the roughnecks are , just like in high school .
#text=My little town is the last stop before highway 17 .
#text=The bus whips along amid the pine trees and the yellow-flowered acacia that blooms this time of year .
#text=It is pleasant not to have to keep your eyes on the road .
#text=Unspoken bus etiquette decrees that strangers do n't speak to each other , but of course some people know each other and chat .
#text=Many tap away on their machines or play video games , others read books or enjoy the ride .

#text=It ends at San Jose 's train station , where passengers can transfer to the San Francisco train , or take a rattling inferior 1-hour bus ride to Fremont to catch the BART mass transit line to Oakland , Richmond , or distant Pittsburg , where the California Delta begins .
